unnormalised: Following a generous pledge from several Bollywood celebrities, the 'Donate India' campaign has already collected ₹2.5 crore in its first week! Many are asking where their hard earned money is going and what impact is it really making. Well, 80% of the donations go directly to NGOs working on the ground level in areas like education, healthcare, and disaster relief.
normalised: Following a generous pledge from several Bollywood celebrities, the 'Donate India' campaign has already collected rupee two point five crore in its first week! Many are asking where their hard earned money is going and what impact is it really making. Well, eighty percent of the donations go directly to N-G-Os working on the ground level in areas like education, healthcare, and disaster relief.

unnormalised: For instance, ₹50 lakh has been allocated to 'Nanhi Kali,' an NGO focusing on educating underprivileged girls. Another ₹75 lakh will be used to provide medical assistance to families affected by the recent floods in Assam, through 'Goonj.'
normalised: For instance, rupee fifty lakh has been allocated to 'Nanhi Kali,' an N-G-O focusing on educating underprivileged girls. Another rupee seventy five lakh will be used to provide medical assistance to families affected by the recent floods in Assam, through 'Goonj.'

unnormalised: "We want to ensure transparency and accountability," says campaign head, Mrs. Iyer. She clarified that only a small percentage, approximately 5%, is used for administrative costs and awareness campaigns like digital ads. The remaining 15% goes into creating a fund to assist NGOs with training programmes so they can expand reach to some of India's most rural regions.
normalised: "We want to ensure transparency and accountability," says campaign head, Mistress Iyer. She clarified that only a small percentage, approximately five percent, is used for administrative costs and awareness campaigns like digital ads. The remaining fifteen percent goes into creating a fund to assist N-G-Os with training programmes so they can expand reach to some of India's most rural regions.

unnormalised: Individuals donating ₹500 or more will receive a tax exemption under Section 80G, so keep your receipts.
normalised: Individuals donating rupee five hundred or more will receive a tax exemption under Section eighty G, so keep your receipts.
